author: robocopsgonemad
content: cool stuff, a couple notes on first review:

author: robocopsgonemad
content:
1) the concept of trustless apis is interesting, but i don't see a need for it outside the section o n lightclients. I would propose that be it's own namespace, instead of spreading the need for trustlessness across the entire api.

2) the idea of switching to a REST api (fine) but also requiring versioning (wat) is problematic. One of the key points of a REST api is to avoid versioning, since there isn't great ways to do it. This is a known controversy among API architects.

3) no mention of callbacks/subscriptions. i think wallets care a lot about these types of apis, and i think we should plan to make this sub-domain more robust and richer as we plan a refactor.

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
I really like the idea of a "core" provable REST/RPC API that all the clients provide and then the providers can further diversify (codebase wise) over that.  I think there'd still be a successor "user level" API spec that all the providers would adhere to, since thats probably what wallets and dapps would talk to, but the logic could be implemented outside of the core clients (like Helios as mentioned in the doc) and the large RPC providers could more easily focus on delivering those APIs "at scale" without having to customize whole clients.

This only works though if the core API is cacheable and built for that use case though: Helios atm actually places more load on the "backing node" since generating the access list requires the backing node to run the full eth_call anyways, plus then generating the proofs.
